The decision to let the gold flows swell the U.S. money supplywas also at least partly a policy choice. The Roosevelt administration chosenot to sterilize the gold flows because they hoped that such flows wouldstimulate the depressed U.S. economy.

31The finding that monetary developments were very important and fiscalpolicy was of little consequence in the mid— and late—1930s suggests aninteresting twist on the usual view that World War II was important in causingor accelerating the recovery from the Great Depression. As mentioned above,even in 1942, the year that the economy returned to its trend path, theeffects of fiscal policy were small.
